Situation1: They are asked to take part in an important family event like a holiday celebration or trip.
Expectation2: Conduct experiments to test hypotheses and gather data
Situation2: The experiment can be run on several upcoming dates, and skipping this slot would not disrupt the overall timeline.
Story:
I stared at the calendar on my phone, my thumb hovering over the “accept” button for the lab’s experiment schedule. The next available slot was the same weekend as our family’s annual holiday trip—a tradition my sister always insisted I join, no matter how busy I was. Mom had already texted twice, reminding me to pack warm clothes and promising my favorite pie. I could almost hear my brother’s teasing if I bailed again. 

But the experiment was important, too. Months of planning had led to this, and my advisor expected me to be there, hands-on, collecting data. The lab was counting on me to keep things moving. I felt the weight of both worlds pressing in: the warmth and laughter of my family, the quiet hum of the lab and the thrill of discovery. I wanted to be the reliable brother, the dedicated scientist. My chest tightened as I realized I couldn’t be both, not this weekend. I scrolled through the messages, torn, knowing I had to choose but wishing I didn’t have to.
